snippet.textDisplay: I think I had/have the Samsung you tested and its sub-60in counter (that broke and SUCKED, darkest and most reflective TV I've ever owned and that was after living in an alcove) and got replaced with an 85in Bravia True HDR 4k 5 grand USD TV and I LOVE and matches its 65in brother in the kitchen (love having a big house to put this stupid shit in). My 85in that I replaced the 58in ( I think it was) sits in front of my entertainment unit, have it set at 15/50 brightness and no issue seeing the images on screen. Also, Samsung's internet implementation sucks. Edit: Your guy is wrong about screen sharing with phones, maybe since mine is a samsung phone, but all my tablets and phones (which covers mostly samsung and my laptop) were able to share their screen with the TV, it was a terrible experience, but it worked. And I have the 55in in my office.
snippet.textOriginal: I think I had/have the Samsung you tested and its sub-60in counter (that broke and SUCKED, darkest and most reflective TV I've ever owned and that was after living in an alcove) and got replaced with an 85in Bravia True HDR 4k 5 grand USD TV and I LOVE and matches its 65in brother in the kitchen (love having a big house to put this stupid shit in). My 85in that I replaced the 58in ( I think it was) sits in front of my entertainment unit, have it set at 15/50 brightness and no issue seeing the images on screen. Also, Samsung's internet implementation sucks. Edit: Your guy is wrong about screen sharing with phones, maybe since mine is a samsung phone, but all my tablets and phones (which covers mostly samsung and my laptop) were able to share their screen with the TV, it was a terrible experience, but it worked. And I have the 55in in my office.

snippet.textDisplay: I have a Vizio, and a TCL, both were cheap, both look great as TV's. The computer may be a bit slow when you switch to the net, but, not that slow. I stood in Costco watching a couple Samsungs around 75-80 inches next to each other, one was $1000 more than the other. I could barely tell a difference between them. Most programming is still in 720-1080P, only some is in 4k, and on a 55 inch, yes, it is clearer, but, not a big deal if it is just a comedy special or something. Honestly, broadcast over the antenna at 1080i is very detailed already at 55 inches, every hair and pore, right there. Unless you go bigger, go cheap.
snippet.textOriginal: I have a Vizio, and a TCL, both were cheap, both look great as TV's. The computer may be a bit slow when you switch to the net, but, not that slow. I stood in Costco watching a couple Samsungs around 75-80 inches next to each other, one was $1000 more than the other. I could barely tell a difference between them. Most programming is still in 720-1080P, only some is in 4k, and on a 55 inch, yes, it is clearer, but, not a big deal if it is just a comedy special or something. Honestly, broadcast over the antenna at 1080i is very detailed already at 55 inches, every hair and pore, right there. Unless you go bigger, go cheap.

snippet.textDisplay: I will never, NEVER, understand why new TV's always come with motion settings ON buy default. You just know that there is millions of normies who are watching a shitty PQ & will never know that they can have better because all they use are the crap default profiles. If people are on the fence about what to buy, the Samsung RU8000 will prolly drop in price to around £500 this year, & it looks great for the price & is good for gaming. Dont bother with the LG counterpart (SM8500) its HDR is total crap, Dolby Vision is pointless on this set, blacks look grey, although its good for gaming.
snippet.textOriginal: I will never, NEVER, understand why new TV's always come with motion settings ON buy default. snippet.textDisplay:
That TCL and the LG looked like the two best options for sure. I have seen the TCL's listed in our Best buys in Canada and they seem to get fairly decent user reviews. I was surprised the Samsung did so poorly over all though. I have a Samsung 60 inch 4K TV and have my main PC hooked to it and yes things like motion settings and some darn Mpeg settings were very annoying more so in games the Mpeg setting forget what it was called made darker scenes in the games make it look like the walls were crawling when you would move the mouse around slightly once I turned that off all of that went away.


I I tried game mode and was not impressed with it as it made the TV super bright and the picture quality went south really quick. I ended up using PC setting on the HDMI port with Movie and changed the default warm 2 to Warm 1 setting. I checked online my inoput lag is about 12-14ms with the HDMI set to PC mode & with it off it is a lot higher. I think that was one of the most noticed changes I made other than turning off that Mpeg setting.
snippet.textOriginal:
That TCL and the LG looked like the two best options for sure. I have seen the TCL's listed in our Best buys in Canada and they seem to get fairly decent user reviews. I was surprised the Samsung did so poorly over all though. I have a Samsung 60 inch 4K TV and have my main PC hooked to it and yes things like motion settings and some darn Mpeg settings were very annoying more so in games the Mpeg setting forget what it was called made darker scenes in the games make it look like the walls were crawling when you would move the mouse around slightly once I turned that off all of that went away.


I I tried game mode and was not impressed with it as it made the TV super bright and the picture quality went south really quick. I ended up using PC setting on the HDMI port with Movie and changed the default warm 2 to Warm 1 setting. I checked online my inoput lag is about 12-14ms with the HDMI set to PC mode & with it off it is a lot higher. I think that was one of the most noticed changes I made other than turning off that Mpeg setting.

snippet.textDisplay:
First of all, James should've had to eat the durian since Linus gottem' all right

Second, this makes me feel pretty good about my $315 Black Friday Vizio M437-g0 43" - absolutely fantastic TV for that price(I believe regular price is around $375), haven't had a single issue, and I'm not even sure what I could nitpick, it's just a damn good TV! If anyone is looking for one around this size and price, you're going to be hard pressed to find anything too much better(I tried during Black Friday lol)

It's INSANE how much TV you can get for the dollar in 2020, the amount of features is ridiculous, but especially the build quality and GUI quality is SO far beyond what it was even 5 years ago.
snippet.textOriginal:

If anyone is looking for one around this size and price, you're going to be hard pressed to find anything too much better(I tried during Black Friday lol)

snippet.textDisplay:
My old plasma took a dive a few months ago and I needed a replacement immediately and on a budget. Having limited space, I ended up with the TCL4 50in. Was expecting "meh" but got a bit more. I had already gotten my parents a 65in 4 series last year, and the 50 looks better than the 65. But I guess that's what pixel density is all about.

Nice to see a reviewer surprised by TCL. Throw in that a lot of older people got used to roku, being a roku based pannel makes the most sense house wide. We have 3. 65 living room, 40 sewing room, 50 basement/media room. (The 50 will be replaced with a 2020/2021 TCL6 65in)
snippet.textOriginal:
My old plasma took a dive a few months ago and I needed a replacement immediately and on a budget. Having limited space, I ended up with the TCL4 50in. Was expecting "meh" but got a bit more. I had already gotten my parents a 65in 4 series last year, and the 50 looks better than the 65. But I guess that's what pixel density is all about. 

Nice to see a reviewer surprised by TCL. Throw in that a lot of older people got used to roku, being a roku based pannel makes the most sense house wide. We have 3. 65 living room, 40 sewing room, 50 basement/media room. (The 50 will be replaced with a 2020/2021 TCL6 65in)

snippet.textDisplay:
You can set the Samsung TV to game mode in the advanced settings (the wrench) in external device settings.


With that you have all processing disabled and low latency always on.

snippet.textDisplay:
Great video, guys!

I love the content about less expensive stuff, and am always appreciative that Linus can step down from the $5000 gear and objectively say that a $279 dollar TV is pretty good looking. (to paraphrase.)

I was actually about to pull the trigger on the very unit in question (The TCL ROKU TV.) The reviews lean well, with several complaints of damage out of the box (bad packaging, perhaps.) But with it actually compared to similar units, I think at price-to-performance it's a clear winner in my budget range. So the video applies nicely to my current needs!
snippet.textOriginal:
Great video, guys!

I love the content about less expensive stuff, and am always appreciative that Linus can step down from the $5000 gear and objectively say that a $279 dollar TV is *pretty good looking.* (to paraphrase.)

I was actually about to pull the trigger on the very unit in question (The TCL ROKU TV.) The reviews lean well, with several complaints of damage out of the box (bad packaging, perhaps.) But with it actually compared to similar units, I think at price-to-performance it's a clear winner in my budget range. So the video applies nicely to my current needs!
